US Business.title: GM and Pilot Plan National Electric-Vehicle Charging Network
US Business.desc: The partnership would add 2,000 fast-charging stalls to 500 Pilot and Flying J locations starting next year.

US Business.title: Baby-Formula Shortage Deepens, Defying Replenishment
US Business.desc: Out-of-stock levels remain high in U.S. stores: “Until those shelves are full, the crisis continues.”

US Business.title: People Have Money but Feel Glum---What Does That Mean for the Economy?
US Business.desc: A robust job market and strong household savings have shielded consumer spending so far, but it is endangered by inflation that now has some households running scared.

US Business.title: Jobless Claims Reach Highest Level This Year
US Business.desc: New applications for unemployment benefits edged higher last week to 244,000 but remained near historic lows.

US Business.title: Producer Price Gains Accelerated in June
US Business.desc: Key reading of producer-level inflation showed an 11.3% annual rate, the seventh straight month of double-digit gains.

US Business.title: Mortgage Rates Rise Again After Recording Sharp Drop
US Business.desc: The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 5.51%, Freddie Mac said. That is up from 5.30% last week, when rates recorded the largest weekly decline since 2008, but below the 13-year high of 5.81% in June.

US Business.title: Fed Official Says 0.75-Point Rate Rise Seems Most Likely in July
US Business.desc: Fed governor Christopher Waller says the central bank needs to raise rates high enough to slow the economy.

US Business.title: Emirates Slams Heathrow Airport, Says It Won't Scrap Flights
US Business.desc: Emirates, one of the world’s biggest airlines, lashed out at Heathrow Airport’s decision earlier this week to limit the number of passengers departing the London hub and said it won’t comply with its request to cut flights to and from the airport.

US Business.title: Amazon Proposes Settlement of EU Antitrust Charges on Seller Data
US Business.desc: The online retailer has proposed concessions to settle two antitrust cases against it in the European Union, a fresh sign of changing strategy from big tech companies after the bloc passed a strict new digital-competition law.

US Business.title: From Gap to Dollar General, Retail CEOs Exit as Complications Grow
US Business.desc: Some companies delayed succession plans in the pandemic, but others are accelerating changes in their C-suites as the industry landscape shifts.

US Business.title: Engine Maker Cummins Names New CEO
US Business.desc: Jennifer Rumsey will take on the CEO role in August as the company pursues cleaner alternatives to diesel engines.

US Business.title: GM Robotaxi Unit Under California Scrutiny Over Launch Readiness
US Business.desc: A California regulator said it is looking into claims made in an anonymous letter that the self-driving car company was preparing to launch its robotaxi service prematurely.

US Business.title: Molson Coors Returns to Super Bowl Ads After AB InBev Ends Exclusivity
US Business.desc: Molson Coors will run at least one commercial during Fox’s Super Bowl broadcast in 2023, marking the first time in more than 30 years that the maker of Coors Light and Miller Lite beer has advertised in the game.

US Business.title: MacBook Air M2 Review: A Better Screen, Processor and Webcam
US Business.desc: Apple’s latest MacBook Air has a faster chip, but the real allure is its bigger, brighter screen and improved webcam, plus the return of klutz-proof MagSafe charging.

US Business.title: Hilcorp, Exxon and Conoco Top Greenhouse Gas Emitters
US Business.desc: New report is based on data oil-and-gas firms submitted to U.S. on emissions of carbon dioxide and methane.

Market.title: NFT Marketplace OpenSea to Lay Off 20% of Employees
Market.desc: The crash in cryptocurrency prices continues to wreak havoc on digital-asset firms.

Market.title: Dow, S&P 500 Slip as Banks Kick Off Earnings Season
Market.desc: U.S. stock indexes were mixed, with the S&P 500 wrapping up its fifth consecutive day of losses as earnings season kicked off with the first reports from major banks.

Market.title: Elliott Sets Sights on Pinterest
Market.desc: Activist investor Elliott Management has taken a big stake in Pinterest, people familiar with the matter say, as the once-hot social-media company grapples with a decline in users and other challenges.

Market.title: Euro Slips Below Dollar as Europe's Economic Fortunes Slump
Market.desc: The euro selloff has intensified as investors gird for a Russian gas cutoff that many fear will drive the region into a recession. But unlike the last time the common currency was this weak 20 years ago, nobody is coming to its rescue.

Market.title: Single-Stock ETFs to Allow U.S. Investors to Make Big Bets on Popular Stocks
Market.desc: AXS Investments plans to launch a set of exchange-traded funds tied to shares of specific companies, such as Nike or Pfizer, that are designed to amplify their daily performance or the inverse of that performance.

Market.title: JPMorgan Chase Sees Economic Turmoil Brewing, but Few Signs of Recession So Far
Market.desc: Second-quarter profit at JPMorgan fell 28% even as the nation’s largest bank said it is seeing few signs a recession is imminent, underscoring the uncertainty looming over markets and the economy.

Market.title: Morgan Stanley Profit Falls 29%
Market.desc: The investment bank’s second-quarter profit fell short of expectations, reflecting a drop in corporate deal making.

Market.title: Bank of America Fined $225 Million for Mishandling Unemployment Benefits
Market.desc: Federal regulators said the bank also must compensate people whose access to funds during the pandemic was denied or delayed.

Market.title: JPMorgan Chase's Defensive Moves Aren't the Whole Story
Market.desc: A reserve build and higher capital requirements obscure some solid underlying business momentum.

Market.title: Parity Is Unlikely to Be the Bottom for the Euro
Market.desc: Parity is an arbitrary but potent symbolic target. There is a chance that many hedges, options contracts and stop-loss orders have been structured to be triggered around this level on the assumption that it will act as a floor. In today’s conditions, such expectations could turn out to be painful.

Market.title: Frustrated Home Buyers in China Threaten to Stop Paying Mortgages
Market.desc: China’s property market has entered a new stage of turmoil after a year-long slide in sales, stalled projects and mounting real-estate developer defaults.

Market.title: Japan Inc. Finally Shows Shareholders the Money
Market.desc: It’s tough times for stocks everywhere. But notoriously tight-fisted Japanese companies are starting to pay out more—some consolation in a bad market.

Market.title: Global Natural-Gas Markets Are Getting Scared
Market.desc: LNG spot market prices have shot up in recent weeks, but could have much further to go if Russia closes its pipeline to Germany.

Market.title: The Ultimate Revenue Driving Machine
Market.desc: BMWs have heated seats and steering wheels, but only if your subscription is up to date.

Market.title: Pharma Is Place to Hide During Recession
Market.desc: Drug stocks may continue to outperform the broader market as investors flock to an industry known for weathering recessions relatively well.

Market.title: Big-Name Investors Pour Billions Into Clean Hydrogen Projects
Market.desc: The newest wager is on a Nebraska startup trying to upend the burgeoning industry of clean hydrogen with a process that uses natural gas but traps carbon by producing an ingredient vital for everyday products like car tires.

Market.title: As Volatility Roils Bonds and Currencies, Stocks Appear Stable
Market.desc: The bond and foreign-exchange markets are undergoing their sharpest bouts of volatility since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. The stock market might have some catching up to do.

Market.title: IRS Gives Wealthy Families More Time to Shelter Assets from Estate Tax
Market.desc: A surviving spouse will now have up to five years to claim larger estate-tax exemption

Tech.title: Amazon Has Been Slashing Private-Label Selection Amid Weak Sales
Tech.desc: Executives also have discussed exiting the business entirely to address regulatory pressure.

Tech.title: Amazon Proposes Settlement of EU Antitrust Charges on Seller Data
Tech.desc: The online retailer has proposed concessions to settle two antitrust cases against it in the European Union, a fresh sign of changing strategy from big tech companies after the bloc passed a strict new digital-competition law.

Tech.title: Elliott Sets Sights on Pinterest
Tech.desc: Activist investor Elliott Management has taken a big stake in Pinterest, people familiar with the matter say, as the once-hot social-media company grapples with a decline in users and other challenges.

Tech.title: SEC Questioned Elon Musk Tweet Over Twitter Deal
Tech.desc: The billionaire is facing scrutiny from securities regulators over whether he promptly disclosed his intention to end his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter after a disagreement over spam-account data.

Tech.title: Alibaba Executives Called In by China Authorities Amid Historic Data Heist
Tech.desc: Following the theft of sensitive Shanghai police data, authorities call in Alibaba executives as the company investigates how one of history’s largest data heists was allowed to happen.

Tech.title: MacBook Air M2 Review: A Better Screen, Processor and Webcam
Tech.desc: Apple’s latest MacBook Air has a faster chip, but the real allure is its bigger, brighter screen and improved webcam, plus the return of klutz-proof MagSafe charging.

Tech.title: Ericsson Boosted by Demand for 5G Equipment but Warns of Rising Costs
Tech.desc: The Swedish telecom-equipment giant said its sales and profit rose in the second quarter as wireless carriers snapped up its 5G gear, but warned of higher costs stemming from geopolitical tensions and inflation.

Tech.title: Cyber Bug in Log4j to Persist as 'Endemic' Risk for Years to Come, U.S. Board Finds
Tech.desc: The flaw in the widely used internet software has so far been less harmful than expected but significant risk remains, the Cyber Safety Review Board says.

Tech.title: Deutsche Telekom Sells Stake in Tower Business for $6.6 Billion
Tech.desc: The German telecoms company said it had agreed to sell a 51% stake in its tower unit in Germany and Austria to Brookfield Infrastructure Partners and DigitalBridge.
